III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The Clarence Fisher Leadership Academy has a central building, consisting of 6 main
areas: platoon bays, chow hall, kitchen, school, training center and administrative
offices.
Platoon bays are divided into 4 areas: the bathroom area, the wall locker area, the area
where group meeting are held, and the rack area where the cadets sleep. The kitchen
is right off the chow hall and consists of a prep area, dishwashing area, walk-in cooler,
dry goods, closet and cooking area. The school consists of 4 main classrooms, for
Math, Science, Social Studies and English, respectively. The training center consists of
a large area for training and various surrounding offices. The administrative offices are
five in number, and are located around the outer wall of the chow hall.
There are also three off-site facilities used by cadets in the program. These include the
GED school testing and teaching area, the Food Distribution Center and the Strength
Training Center. The GED class building consists of two rooms – one room for teaching
and preparing youths for GED testing and the other room for taking the GED test. The
Food Distribution Center consists of two offices, a large dry goods storage area, a
dishwashing area, three walk-in coolers/freezers, and an area for cutting and
processing meats. The Strength Training area consists of a cardio-vascular workout
area, a weight lifting area, 2 offices and 2 shower/changing rooms.
B. Program Description
The Clarence Fisher Leadership Academy is a residential treatment program with a
capacity to serve 78 male youths. The Academy provides 24-hour-per-day care to
youths that are 12 to 17 years of age at the time of admission. The average length of
stay is 6 months, varying primarily on the commitment orders of each youth and their
dedication to their treatment program.
The goal of the CFLA is to provide for the social, moral, emotional, educational, and
sustenance needs of all its residents, and to bring about behavioral change through
peaceful coexistence. The principles taught in the program are reality, respect,
2

responsibility, communication, negotiation, education and love. They are taught through
an eclectic approach to social treatment.
The milieu is structured by a behavioral point-level system/token economy, called the
Motivation and Learning System. Robert Wollack developed this system in the 1970’s.
This treatment approach, combined with Glasser’s Reality Therapy, comprises the
primary treatment modality in all of Wolverine’s programs. What makes the CFLA
program different is the incorporation of military structure and discipline, which teaches
youth appropriate self-confidence and self-control, facilitates effective interaction with
authority figures, and develops polite pro-social communication and behavior.
The CFLA program includes pre-vocational and vocational training, group, individual,
family and substance abuse counseling, gang related behavior intervention and social
skills development and enhancement. The program also provides work
skills development, basic, special, and health education services, physical fitness
and recreational activities, medical and dental care, on site family visitation,
transportation services for the families of youths, post-placement planning and
psychological/psychiatric services.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The Clarence Fisher Leadership Academy program was reviewed as part of the
overall Pioneer Work and Learn Center review conducted May 7, 18, 19 and 21,
2004. All identified rule violations have been corrected, and the facility is in
compliance with all applicable rule areas. A full review of the Clarence Fisher
Leadership Academy program will be conducted at the end of the six month Original
Provisional period.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that an Original Provisional License be issued effective 9/2/2004.
